channel.title: Comments on: Force installation of 64-bit ACE OLE DB provider
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: sri
item.dc:creator: sri
item.description: hi I am using excel source connection in ssis in connection it is showing excel 12.0 version but I am using excel is excel 2016 and also in registry I am able to see typeguessrows is in 16.0 so how I need to sync with excel connection and registry
item.content:encoded: hi I am using excel source connection in ssis in connection it is showing excel 12.0 version but I am using excel is excel 2016 and also in registry I am able to see typeguessrows is in 16.0 so how I need to sync with excel connection and registry

item.title: By: renu
item.dc:creator: renu
item.description: I'm using windows 7,excel 2007,sql server 2008. When I'm trying to import an excel sheet to sql table I'm getting this error even if after installing ACE drivers. I installed in my local machine,not in dev server.Please help me
item.content:encoded: I’m using windows 7,excel 2007,sql server 2008. When I’m trying to import an excel sheet to sql table I’m getting this error even if after installing ACE drivers. I installed in my local machine,not in dev server.Please help me

item.title: By: Danny Teok
item.dc:creator: Danny Teok
item.description: Slightly unclear still. I have a 64-bit Windows 7 machine and the Office 2013 packages are in 64-bit. Even if I'm running SSIS 2012, you're saying that the SSDT is running in 32-bit mode? If that is the case, what do I have to do?
item.content:encoded:
Slightly unclear still. I have a 64-bit Windows 7 machine and the Office 2013 packages are in 64-bit.
Even if I’m running SSIS 2012, you’re saying that the SSDT is running in 32-bit mode? If that is the case, what do I have to do?

item.title: By: Gosta M
item.dc:creator: Gosta M
item.description: Thank you Koen.<br /> SSIS and Excel is not a good marriage. If you work with your own computer then you can fidle around with "work arounds" but as a consultant for a company with strict rules that might be impossible. If you only want to pull some data out from a sheet in Excel, make a small macro which saves the data as a TAB separated text file and use bulk insert or SSIS. If you want to push data (actual values) and pull out data (prognose) from the same sheet consider use VBA. With VBA you can build a "front end" to SQL Server with Excel. <br />
item.content:encoded:
Thank you Koen.
SSIS and Excel is not a good marriage. If you work with your own computer then you can fidle around with “work arounds” but as a consultant for a company with strict rules that might be impossible. If you only want to pull some data out from a sheet in Excel, make a small macro which saves the data as a TAB separated text file and use bulk insert or SSIS. If you want to push data (actual values) and pull out data (prognose) from the same sheet consider use VBA. With VBA you can build a “front end” to SQL Server with Excel.

item.title: By: jdbrauer
item.dc:creator: jdbrauer
item.content:encoded:
Ah, I have confirmed what Stewart observed: 32-bit Office apps stop working after forcing installation of the 64-bit ACE driver. Excel is no longer able to open files after installing 64-bit ACE driver, but this can be reversed by uninstalling the 64-bit driver and reinstalling 32-bit.
Will evidently need to decide which tool is more important: SQL Server openrowset queries, or Excel itself. Or bite the bullet and replace 32-bit Office with 64-bit.
Agree with Stewart that Microsoft could/should do better than this.

item.title: By: Koen Verbeeck
item.dc:creator: Koen Verbeeck
item.content:encoded:
@Stewart: the ACE providers are a little disaster. I installed the 32-bit provider on my 64-bit machine with 64-bit Office. All worked fine as described in the blog, until I wanted to repair my office install. I got an error saying I had to uninstall the 32-bit driver first.

@jdbrauer: good to know your problem was solved!

item.title: By: jdbrauer
item.dc:creator: jdbrauer
item.description: Koen, thanks so much for posting this with the pointer to Lowell's solution for installing the 64-bit ACE driver on a machine with 32-bit Office apps. It solved my problem - I can now run openrowset queries against Excel files.
item.content:encoded: Koen, thanks so much for posting this with the pointer to Lowell’s solution for installing the 64-bit ACE driver on a machine with 32-bit Office apps. It solved my problem – I can now run openrowset queries against Excel files.

item.title: By: Stewart McGuire
item.dc:creator: Stewart McGuire
item.description: I have Office 2010 32-bit installed and I tried installing the 64-bit ACE using the /passive switch. It installed without complaints and the 64-bit connectivity appeared to work. HOWEVER, my 32-bit Access refused to start! Every time I tried to open Access it would go through an Office setup configuration process and then fail to open with some sort of configuration error. :-( As soon as I uninstalled the 64-bit ACE my Access started working again. Not sure why this happened but it is VERY annoying that MS didn't write their 32-bit and 64-bit ACE drivers to play nice alongside each other.
item.content:encoded: I have Office 2010 32-bit installed and I tried installing the 64-bit ACE using the /passive switch. It installed without complaints and the 64-bit connectivity appeared to work. HOWEVER, my 32-bit Access refused to start! Every time I tried to open Access it would go through an Office setup configuration process and then fail to open with some sort of configuration error. üôÅ As soon as I uninstalled the 64-bit ACE my Access started working again. Not sure why this happened but it is VERY annoying that MS didn’t write their 32-bit and 64-bit ACE drivers to play nice alongside each other.

item.title: By: remou
item.dc:creator: remou
item.description: I have the 32 bit 2007 drivers and the 64 bit 2010 drivers. This works quite well and installs without offering me any arguments as to why it is not allowed.
item.content:encoded: I have the 32 bit 2007 drivers and the 64 bit 2010 drivers. This works quite well and installs without offering me any arguments as to why it is not allowed.
